title: Magiritsa
text:
Magiritsa () is a <a href="Greek%20cuisine">Greek</a> <a href="soup">soup</a> made from <a href="domestic%20sheep">lamb</a> offal, associated with the <a href="Easter">Easter</a> (Pascha) tradition of the <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox%20Church">Greek Orthodox Church</a>. Accordingly, Greek-Americans and Greek-Canadians sometimes call it "Easter soup", "Easter Sunday soup", or "Easter lamb soup". In some parts of Greece, most notably <a href="Thessaly">Thessaly</a>, it is not served as soup but rather as a <a href="fricassee">fricassee</a>, where it contains only offal and large variety of vegetables, but no onions or rice, as in the soup.
Traditional use.
Magiritsa is eaten to break the <a href="fasting">fast</a> of the <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox%20Church">Greek Orthodox</a> <a href="Great%20Lent">Great Lent</a>, the 40 days before Easter. Its role and ingredients result from its association with the roasted lamb traditionally served at the Paschal meal; in its traditional form, magiritsa consists of the offal removed from the lamb before roasting, flavored with seasonings and sauces. Prepared on <a href="Holy%20Saturday">Holy Saturday</a> along with the next day's lamb, magiritsa is consumed immediately after the midnight Divine Liturgy.
Ingredients and preparation.
While traditional magiritsa includes all the lamb offal available, it is the <a href="head">head</a> and <a href="neck">neck</a> of the lamb which provide most of the soup's flavor, and those parts, along with the <a href="intestines">intestines</a>, <a href="heart">heart</a>, and <a href="liver">liver</a>, are most commonly used today.
After a thorough cleaning, the lamb parts are boiled whole in water for between thirty minutes and two hours, then cut up into smaller pieces, flavored with <a href="onions">onions</a>, <a href="dill">dill</a>, <a href="butter">butter</a> and sometimes <a href="vegetables">vegetables</a>, and left to <a href="simmer">simmer</a>. <a href="Rice">Rice</a> is added towards the end of the boiling process, and the stock is thickened with <a href="avgolemono">avgolemono</a>.
When consumed in the early hours of the Paschal morning after church, magiritsa is sometimes accompanied by <a href="salad">salad</a> and <a href="cheese">cheese</a>, <a href="tsoureki">tsoureki</a> sweet bread, and hard-boiled <a href="egg%20%28food%29">eggs</a> dyed red as a symbol of the <a href="Resurrection%20of%20Jesus">risen Christ</a>'s blood.
